wiki_catalogs.name: Introduction
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the introduction section focused on the SETUNA screenshot capture application. Explain its purpose as a lightweight, high-DPI-compatible Windows desktop tool designed for capturing and managing persistent image 'scraps' on-screen. Highlight key features such as multi-monitor DPI support, system tray integration, global hotkeys, and persistent scrap restoration after restart. Describe the target audience, including power users and developers needing quick access to annotated screenshots. Provide context on the project's evolution from Setuna2, its current maintenance status, and licensing considerations. Include practical examples of common use cases like documentation, design feedback, and clipboard enhancement. Address prerequisites such as .NET Framework 4.7 and Windows 10 14393+. Reference the README.md for visual examples and version-specific requirements.

wiki_catalogs.name: Capture Modes
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for capture modes including full-screen, region-based, and click-to-capture workflows. Explain the implementation logic in CaptureForm for handling different capture triggers and selection strategies. Document how ClickCapture enables single-click screenshot capture without region selection. Describe the role of CaptureInfo in storing metadata such as capture source, timestamp, and screen resolution. Include code examples showing how SelLineType influences visual feedback during selection. Address configuration options for including mouse cursor and handling multi-monitor setups. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like incorrect screen bounds detection and performance bottlenecks during high-frequency capture.

wiki_catalogs.name: Scrap Lifecycle Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for scrap lifecycle management focused on the creation, persistence, and destruction of captured images. Explain how ScrapBook acts as the central registry, managing the addition of new scraps via AddScrap and AddScrapFromCache methods, and handling their removal through ScrapClose. Detail the role of ScrapBase in representing individual scrap windows, including initialization in its constructor and cleanup in ScrapClose and ~ScrapBase. Document the interaction between ScrapBook and ScrapBase for event registration, particularly the ScrapCloseEvent that triggers removal from the registry. Include practical examples of scrap creation from both capture and cache restoration, and describe the behavior of the dustbox (recycle bin) with capacity management and automatic cleanup. Address common issues such as memory leaks during disposal and edge cases in event deregistration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Mainform - Central UI Controller
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Mainform class as the central UI controller of the SETUNA application. Explain its role as the primary Windows Form that manages the system tray icon, user interactions, and coordination between core components. Detail its responsibilities including handling capture initiation, option management, hotkey processing via WndProc, and integration with the ScrapBook for scrap lifecycle management. Document its implementation of multiple listener interfaces (IScrapKeyPressEventListener, IScrapAddedListener, etc.) for event-driven communication. Describe the initialization sequence in the constructor and Load event, including integration with SingletonApplication for single-instance enforcement. Include usage examples of how Mainform coordinates between UI actions and backend services like CacheManager and LayerManager. Address common issues such as hotkey registration failures and provide troubleshooting guidance.

wiki_catalogs.name: Style System Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the style system architecture that enables modular image manipulation on scraps. Explain the role of CStyle as a container for organizing multiple CStyleItem transformations and how it implements IScrapStyle for integration with the scrap lifecycle. Detail the abstract CStyleItem base class that defines the contract for all style operations, including Apply methods, UI integration through GetToolBoxForm, and cloning capabilities. Describe the execution flow when a style is applied via Apply(ref ScrapBase, Point) and how exceptions are handled. Illustrate how CStyle maintains collections of CStyleItem instances and KeyItems for hotkey binding. Provide code examples showing how CStyle.Apply delegates to ScrapBase.ApplyStyles and how CStyleItem.Apply is implemented in concrete subclasses. Address architectural decisions such as using inheritance over composition for extensibility and the implications of deep copying via MemberwiseClone.

wiki_catalogs.name: Cache Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the CacheManager and CacheItem components. Describe the singleton pattern used in CacheManager and its role as an event listener for scrap lifecycle events (added, removed, location changed, image changed, style applied/removed). Explain how CacheManager orchestrates the creation, persistence, and restoration of CacheItem instances. Document the interaction between CacheManager and ScrapBook during application startup to restore cached scraps asynchronously. Include details on thread safety considerations, error handling during cache operations, and performance implications of sequential restoration. Illustrate the component relationships with a diagram showing CacheManager's dependencies on scrap events and its delegation to CacheItem for data storage.

wiki_catalogs.name: General Settings
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the general settings focused on application-wide behavior and startup configuration. Explain how the SetunaOption class manages application type (ApplicationMode vs ResidentMode), window visibility, and splash screen preferences through the SetunaOptionData inner class. Detail the UI implementation in OptionForm's '常规' (General) tab, including the operation type radio buttons, main window visibility checkbox, and splash window toggle. Document the relationship with AutoStartup.cs for managing Windows startup entries. Include practical examples of configuring top-most behavior, startup type, and cache directory access. Address common issues like settings not persisting after restart and migration between application modes. Explain how these settings affect core application behavior such as system tray presence and window management.

wiki_catalogs.name: Main Window Interface
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the Mainform class, which serves as the primary application window. Explain its role in initializing core components such as ScrapBook, SetunaOption, and the dustbox queue. Document the singleton pattern via the static Instance property and its use in global access. Describe the UI layout with capture and option buttons, system tray integration through NotifyIcon, and event handlers for startup, closing, and visibility. Include examples of form initialization, interaction with the ScrapBook for scrap lifecycle management, and handling of global application state. Address common issues like delayed initialization using delayInitTimer and proper resource disposal. Provide performance tips for minimizing UI thread blocking during startup and restoration of persistent scraps.

wiki_catalogs.name: Hotkey Registration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the hotkey registration mechanism. Explain how HotkeyControl leverages the Windows API via SendMessage to register global hotkeys using the HKCOMB and HKM_SETHOTKEY messages. Document the bit manipulation logic used to encode modifier keys (Ctrl, Shift, Alt) and virtual key codes into the WPARAM parameter. Describe the role of the CreateParams override in assigning the native msctls_hotkey32 window class. Include code examples showing how the Hotkey property getter and setter interact with the underlying Windows control. Address common issues such as failed registrations due to key conflicts and provide troubleshooting guidance for debugging registration failures. Explain performance considerations of global hotkey registration and best practices for minimizing system impact.

wiki_catalogs.name: CStyle Container Pattern
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the CStyle class as the container pattern implementation that organizes multiple CStyleItem transformations. Explain how CStyle implements IScrapStyle, ICloneable, IKeyItemListener, and IStyleMenu interfaces to integrate with the scrap lifecycle, configuration system, hotkey binding, and UI menu rendering. Detail the internal management of CStyleItem collections through the _styles list and array-based property accessors, including AddStyle, RemoveStyle, ClearStyle, and ReplaceStyle operations. Describe the role of KeyItem integration for hotkey assignment via _keys list and methods like AddKeyItem and ClearKey. Illustrate how Apply methods delegate to ScrapBase.ApplyStyles with proper exception handling. Provide code examples showing style execution flow and demonstrate DeepCopy implementation that ensures deep cloning of both the style container and its items. Address architectural decisions such as using MemberwiseClone for shallow copying and the implications for object lifecycle management.

wiki_catalogs.name: WebP Image Format Support
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for WebP image format integration. Explain how WebPWrapper.cs enables encoding and decoding of WebP images through native libwebp library interop. Document core functionality including lossy and lossless encoding, thumbnail generation (fast and quality modes), and metadata extraction via GetInfo. Detail the AdvancedEncode method's use of WebPConfig for tuning compression parameters like quality, speed, and preprocessing. Describe the IDisposable implementation for resource cleanup. Include practical examples of saving screenshots in WebP format and converting clipboard images. Address common issues such as DLL loading failures on different architectures (x86/x64), version compatibility with libwebp, and handling of alpha channels. Provide performance benchmarks comparing WebP with PNG/JPEG and optimization tips for web sharing.

wiki_catalogs.name: Style Item Panel Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the configuration UI panels implementing IStyleItemPanel. Explain how each panel—ScaleStyleItemPanel, OpacityStyleItemPanel, PicasaStyleItemPanel, and CompactStyleItemPanel—provides a specialized interface for configuring its corresponding style item. Document the implementation of SetStyleItem and GetStyleItem methods, including property binding, input validation, and event handling. Provide concrete examples showing how user interactions in ScaleStyleItemPanel update CScaleStyleItem scale values, or how OpacityStyleItemPanel adjusts transparency levels. Describe the integration with ToolBoxForm and the role of GetToolBoxForm in displaying the panel. Address UI state persistence across invocations and accessibility features such as keyboard navigation and screen reader support. Include troubleshooting tips for common issues like unresponsive inputs or incorrect value binding.

wiki_catalogs.name: Transformation Styles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for transformation style items that modify the geometric properties of captured scraps. Explain how CScaleStyleItem enables zooming with fixed or incremental scaling modes, including interpolation quality settings and UI panel integration. Document CRotateStyleItem's implementation of rotation (90°, 180°, 270°) and reflection (vertical/horizontal) operations using GDI+'s RotateFlip method, with automatic window resizing when orientation changes. Include usage examples such as creating scaled references or rotating screenshots, configuration parameters like scale percentages and rotation angles, and performance considerations for image resampling. Address common issues like aspect ratio distortion and provide troubleshooting guidance for unexpected layout changes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Predefined Styles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for predefined styles implementation in the CPreStyles class. Explain how the GetPreStyleList method returns a static collection of built-in style objects such as CCloseStyle, CSeparatorStyle, and CCaptureStyle. Document how the GetPreStyle method enables lookup of predefined styles by StyleID. Describe the role of these predefined styles in providing core application functionality like scrap management, shutdown operations, and version display. Provide examples of how these styles are integrated into the context menu system through CScrapListStyle and CDustBoxStyle. Explain the design rationale behind using static instantiation for predefined styles and how this ensures consistent behavior across application instances. Address how new predefined styles can be added to the system and their relationship with the style ID enumeration.

wiki_catalogs.name: WebP Encoding
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for WebP encoding functionality in the application. Explain how the WebPWrapper class implements lossy, lossless, and near-lossless encoding through the libwebp native library interop. Document the public methods: Save, EncodeLossy, EncodeLossless, and EncodeNearLossless, including their parameters, return values, and error handling. Detail the AdvancedEncode method's role in applying WebPConfig settings such as quality, speed, preprocessing, and alpha channel optimization. Describe the internal use of UnsafeNativeMethods for P/Invoke calls to WebPEncodeBGR/BGRA and WebPEncodeLossless functions. Include practical examples of converting Bitmap objects to WebP byte arrays for clipboard operations and file saving. Address common issues such as pixel format restrictions (only Format24bppRgb and Format32bppArgb supported), maximum image dimensions (16383x16383), and architecture-specific DLL loading. Provide performance guidance on speed vs. compression trade-offs and use cases for each encoding mode.

wiki_catalogs.name: CStyleItem Base Class
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the CStyleItem abstract base class that serves as the foundation for all style item plugins. Explain its implementation of IScrapStyle and ICloneable interfaces, and document key properties such as IsSetting, StateText, NameAndState, IsTerminate, and IsInitApply. Detail the core Apply method overloads that execute image transformations on ScrapBase instances, including the ref parameter pattern for object modification and out parameter for operation delay control. Describe the lifecycle methods GetToolBoxForm and SetTunedStyleItem for UI integration and configuration persistence. Explain the cloning mechanism using MemberwiseClone and its role in style duplication. Provide examples from derived classes like COpacityStyleItem and CScaleStyleItem to illustrate implementation patterns. Address common issues such as state management across clones and proper disposal of unmanaged resources in derived classes. Include performance considerations when applying transformations to multiple scraps.

wiki_catalogs.name: Scaling Operations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for CScaleStyleItem's implementation of image scaling operations. Explain the two modes: Fixed (absolute percentage between 10% and 200%) and Increment (relative adjustment from -190% to +190%). Document how the Scale property on ScrapBase is modified and how UI feedback is provided via StateText showing '原始大小', '% 固定', '% 扩大', or '% 缩小'. Detail the interpolation quality settings (HighQualityBicubic, HighQualityBilinear, NearestNeighbor) and their automatic cycling behavior when 'Low' mode is selected. Include practical examples such as creating zoomed reference images or incrementally resizing scraps. Address performance implications of different interpolation modes and provide troubleshooting guidance for blurry output or unexpected scale resets.

wiki_catalogs.name: Freehand Drawing Tools
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the freehand drawing functionality powered by CPaintStyleItem and PenTool. Explain how CPaintStyleItem initiates the ScrapPaintWindow interface and delegates to PenTool for brush-based drawing operations. Document the implementation of variable pen width, opacity control, and erase mode using the special pink color (PenTool.EraseColor). Describe the drawing workflow including mouse event handling (MouseDown, MouseMove, MouseUp), command history via ToolCommand, and real-time rendering. Include integration with ScrapPaintToolBar for tool selection and ScrapPaintWindow's layer management system. Provide usage examples such as highlighting regions or annotating diagrams, configuration options for brush properties, and troubleshooting guidance for performance issues with complex strokes or rendering glitches. Address undo/redo mechanics and memory management for large drawings.

wiki_catalogs.name: Tone Reverse Style
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the CToneReverseStyleItem class that implements a negative image effect by inverting RGB color values using GDI+ ColorMatrix transformations. Explain how the ColorMatrix is configured with -1 scaling factors and 255 offsets to achieve tone reversal, and detail its integration within the style system via the ApplyStyle method. Include practical examples such as enhancing contrast for visually impaired users or creating photographic negatives. Document implementation specifics including bitmap cloning, Graphics object usage, and pixel format handling. Address common issues like incorrect color space interpretation or performance degradation on high-resolution scraps, and provide troubleshooting guidance for unexpected output such as washed-out colors. Highlight performance considerations when applying this effect to multiple scraps simultaneously and suggest optimization strategies like bitmap disposal and thread-safe rendering.

wiki_catalogs.name: Lossy Encoding
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for lossy WebP encoding functionality. Explain how the EncodeLossy methods work with the libwebp library to compress Bitmap objects using quality-based compression. Document the two overloads: the simple version with quality parameter and the advanced version with speed parameter. Detail how the method validates input (pixel format, dimensions), locks bitmap data, and calls the appropriate UnsafeNativeMethods (WebPEncodeBGR/EncodeBGRA). Include practical examples of using lossy encoding for clipboard operations and file saving. Address common issues such as quality vs. file size trade-offs, supported pixel formats (Format24bppRgb and Format32bppArgb), and maximum image dimensions (16383x16383). Provide performance guidance on choosing appropriate quality settings for different use cases.

wiki_catalogs.name: WebP Metadata Extraction
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the GetInfo method in WebPWrapper.cs that extracts metadata from WebP byte arrays. Explain how it retrieves image dimensions (width, height), detects alpha channel presence, determines animation status, and identifies format type (lossy, lossless, or undefined). Document the internal use of WebPBitstreamFeatures and WebPGetFeatures from the native libwebp library. Provide practical examples of using GetInfo to validate WebP data integrity before decoding, check for transparency support, and determine appropriate rendering pathways. Address common issues such as handling corrupted WebP headers, interpreting edge cases in format detection, and performance implications of metadata extraction. Include code snippets demonstrating pre-processing validation workflows and error handling strategies for malformed input data.

wiki_catalogs.name: Basic WebP Decoding
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for basic WebP decoding functionality using the WebPWrapper class. Explain the implementation of the Load and Decode methods, including how raw WebP byte arrays are processed into GDI+ Bitmap objects. Document the internal workflow: pinning memory with GCHandle, detecting image dimensions and alpha channel presence via WebPGetFeatures, creating appropriately formatted Bitmap objects (Format24bppRgb or Format32bppArgb), and using WebPDecodeBGR/BGRAInto for direct pixel data copying. Include practical examples of loading WebP files from disk and decoding clipboard image data. Address common issues such as exception handling during decode failures, proper disposal of pinned memory, and ensuring libwebp DLL availability through ResourceExtractor. Highlight performance considerations for synchronous decoding and memory usage patterns.

wiki_catalogs.name: Simple Transformation Styles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for implementing simple transformation style items such as opacity adjustment and scaling. Explain how these styles extend CStyleItem and override core methods like Apply(), GetDisplayName(), and GetIcon(). Document the pattern of using basic numeric properties (e.g., opacity percentage, scale factor) and their validation within property setters. Detail how the StateText property reflects current configuration values in the UI. Provide examples from COpacityStyleItem and CScaleStyleItem showing direct image manipulation without user interaction. Describe how these styles integrate with the StyleItemDictionary for discovery and registration. Include guidance on implementing property validation, ensuring thread-safe UI updates, and handling edge cases like invalid scale values. Address common issues such as incorrect state display, property persistence bugs, and performance impacts of repeated transformations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Installation and Setup
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the installation and setup section. Explain system requirements including Windows 10 version 14393+, .NET Framework 4.7, and x86 platform configuration. Document step-by-step installation procedures for both binary distribution and development build from source. Include instructions for initial configuration such as enabling high-DPI support, setting up auto-start, and configuring display settings. Provide guidance on resolving common setup issues like blurry captures (via 'penetration capture' setting) and screen scaling problems. Reference the 初始配置.txt for build-time setup and README.md for runtime configuration paths. Include troubleshooting tips for different Windows versions and DPI scenarios.

wiki_catalogs.name: Selection Tools
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for selection tools used during screenshot capture. Explain how CaptureSelLine renders visual feedback (crosshair, borders, transparency) during region selection using GDI+ drawing operations. Document the SelLineType enumeration that defines different visual styles for selection (e.g., dashed, solid, transparent). Describe how RGBColor manages custom color schemes for selection lines and overlays. Provide code examples showing how visual elements are drawn in real-time based on user drag actions. Address integration with WindowsAPI for capturing accurate pixel data under the cursor. Include performance optimization techniques for smooth rendering during fast mouse movements and high-DPI scaling considerations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Window Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for window management focused on the visual and interactive behavior of scrap windows. Explain how ScrapBase, derived from BaseForm, manages its appearance and user interaction through properties like Opacity, Scale, Padding, and SolidFrame. Detail the implementation of drag-and-drop functionality via DragStart, DragEnd, and DragMove methods, and the visual feedback provided by the opacity change during drag. Describe the window's painting logic in OnPaint, including image scaling and background transparency. Document the handling of window state changes such as activation, deactivation, and mouse hover, which trigger opacity and margin changes based on ActiveOpacity, InactiveOpacity, and RollOverOpacity. Include practical examples of how these properties are used to create a dynamic user interface and address common issues like flickering during drag operations or incorrect opacity states.

wiki_catalogs.name: ScrapBook - Central Registry
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the ScrapBook class as the central registry for all captured image scraps in the SETUNA application. Describe its role as the container that manages the collection of ScrapBase instances, including active scraps and those in the dustbox (recycle bin). Detail its core functionality including adding scraps via AddScrap and AddScrapThenDo methods, handling scrap removal with proper dustbox management, and providing enumeration through GetEnumerator. Explain its event-driven architecture with KeyPress, ScrapAdded, and ScrapRemoved events that enable loose coupling with other components. Document the relationship between ScrapBook and Mainform through the BindForm property, and its integration with CacheManager for persistence. Include practical examples of scrap lifecycle management and demonstrate how WClickStyle applies default styles to newly created scraps. Address performance considerations for large numbers of scraps and memory management through proper disposal.

wiki_catalogs.name: Style Item Types and Functionalities
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the various style item types that provide specific image manipulation capabilities. Explain how StyleItemDictionary serves as a registry for all available style items and enables discovery through GetAllStyleItems and GetStyleType methods. Document each major style category: transformation (CScaleStyleItem, CRotateStyleItem), painting (CPaintStyleItem, TextTool), and special effects (CToneReverseStyleItem, CTimerStyleItem). For each type, describe its implementation, user interface panel (e.g., ScaleStyleItemPanel), and interaction patterns. Provide concrete examples from the codebase such as how CToneReverseStyleItem inverts pixel colors or how CTimerStyleItem creates countdown overlays. Include usage scenarios, configuration options, and performance considerations for complex operations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Storage Format
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the CacheItem data storage format. Detail the structure of the cache directory organized by timestamp (CreateTime.ToCustomString()) with each scrap stored in a dedicated folder. Explain the two-file persistence mechanism: Info.json storing metadata (CreateTime, Position, Style ID, ClickPoint, SortingOrder) in JSON format using Newtonsoft.Json, and Image.png storing the screenshot as a PNG file. Document the schema of the JSON structure including field types and constraints. Describe how ScrapSource and its derivatives (ScrapSourceImage, ScrapSourcePath, ScrapSourceUrl) maintain image provenance and how this information could be extended in future versions. Include examples of actual JSON content and file system layout.

wiki_catalogs.name: Capture Settings
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the capture settings sub-component. Thoroughly explain implementation details of selection area transparency, selection line style (solid/dotted), and background colors through the SetunaOptionData properties SelectAreaTransparent, SelectLineSolid, and color components. Detail the UI implementation in OptionForm's '截取设置' (Capture Settings) tab, including numeric up-down controls, color pickers, and duplication behavior radio buttons. Explain the relationship with CaptureForm.cs for applying these visual settings during screenshot selection. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing default values (80% transparency, dark blue background) and how user modifications are persisted. Address common issues like color picker functionality, transparency level constraints, and the impact of duplication settings on application instances. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers regarding GDI+ rendering implications.

wiki_catalogs.name: Context Menu System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for the ContextStyleMenuStrip class that powers all context menus in the application. Detail its inheritance from ToolStripDropDownMenu and integration with Scraps via the Scrap property. Explain the event-driven behavior on Opened and Closed events, including dynamic menu population based on available styles. Document its use in both the system tray icon (setunaIconMenu) and individual scrap right-click menus. Describe how it enables runtime style application through ToolStripStyleButton instances. Include code examples showing menu customization, event handling for opening/closing, and association with specific Scraps. Address accessibility considerations and high-DPI scaling for menu rendering. Troubleshoot common issues like menu positioning and event leakage.

wiki_catalogs.name: Message Handling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the hotkey message handling system. Explain how the application intercepts WM_HOTKEY messages through the message loop and maps them to specific HotKeyID enum values. Document the HotkeyMsg form's role in notifying users when hotkey registration fails due to conflicts with other applications. Detail the implementation of the HotKey property setter that formats and displays the conflicting key combination in the UI. Describe the event flow from low-level Windows message receipt to high-level application action invocation. Provide examples from the codebase showing how captured hotkeys trigger screenshot operations. Address security implications of global message handling and strategies for preventing unauthorized input interception. Include debugging techniques for tracing hotkey message delivery issues.

wiki_catalogs.name: CStyleItem Extensibility Mechanism
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the CStyleItem abstract base class that defines the extensibility mechanism for all image manipulation operations. Explain the contract enforced by abstract methods including Apply(ref ScrapBase, Point), GetName, GetDisplayName, GetDescription, and GetIcon, which must be implemented by concrete style items. Detail the protected abstract methods GetToolBoxForm and SetTunedStyleItem that enable UI integration and configuration persistence through dedicated form panels. Describe the IsSetting property that determines whether a configuration UI exists and the StyleItemSetting method that orchestrates the configuration workflow. Illustrate the Apply overload that supports asynchronous operations via out waitinterval parameter and the role of _waitinterval field. Explain metadata properties like StateText and NameAndState that provide runtime status display, and lifecycle flags such as IsTerminate and IsInitApply. Provide code examples from concrete implementations like COpacityStyleItem or CScaleStyleItem to show how the base class is extended. Address the cloning mechanism using MemberwiseClone and its implications for state management in derived classes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Embedded Resource Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for embedded native library management. Explain how ResourceExtractor.cs handles extraction of libwebp_x86.dll and libwebp_x64.dll from assembly resources to the filesystem. Document the ExtractWebP method's architecture detection logic using IntPtr.Size to determine platform bitness. Describe the ExtractResourceToFile utility for generic embedded resource deployment. Include the lazy extraction pattern that prevents redundant file operations. Provide examples of how this enables zero-configuration deployment of native dependencies. Address common issues like file permission errors, antivirus interference with DLL extraction, and path resolution in different execution contexts. Include guidelines for extending this system to support additional native libraries.

wiki_catalogs.name: IStyleItemPanel Interface Contract
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the IStyleItemPanel interface as the foundation of the style configuration UI system. Explain its role in decoupling style logic from user interface components, enabling extensible and modular UI design. Detail the two core methods: SetStyleItem for initializing the panel with a style item, and GetStyleItem for retrieving the configured result. Describe how this contract supports dynamic loading of configuration dialogs through reflection or factory patterns. Provide examples of how CStyleItem implementations interact with their corresponding panels. Discuss design considerations such as thread safety, data encapsulation, and error handling during property transfer. Include guidance for developers creating new style item panels, emphasizing adherence to the interface contract and integration with the existing UI framework.

wiki_catalogs.name: Painting and Annotation Styles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for painting and annotation style items that enable direct modification of scrap images. Explain how CPaintStyleItem launches the ScrapPaintWindow modal interface for freehand drawing, text insertion, and shape tools. Document the integration between CPaintStyleItem and the painting subsystem including tool selection (pen, text), color management, and layer handling. Describe the TextTool implementation for adding textual annotations with font and positioning options. Include usage scenarios like highlighting areas of interest or adding explanatory notes, configuration options for brush size and text properties, and performance considerations for complex drawings. Address common issues such as undo/redo functionality and provide troubleshooting guidance for rendering artifacts.

wiki_catalogs.name: User-Defined Styles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for user-defined style management in the SetunaOption class. Explain how the Styles collection stores custom CStyle objects created by users, with each style containing multiple CStyleItem operations and associated hotkeys. Document the FindStyle method's role in retrieving user-defined styles by ID. Describe the StyleEditForm's functionality in creating and modifying custom styles, including its integration with the Style property to bind to CStyle objects. Detail the process of adding style items through the InsertStyleItem method and managing hotkey assignments via the KeyItem system. Explain how the WriteValue method persists style configuration changes. Provide examples of complex user-defined styles that combine multiple operations like scaling, opacity adjustment, and border styling. Address validation rules and error handling during style creation.

wiki_catalogs.name: WebP Decoding
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for WebP decoding functionality. Explain how the WebPWrapper class decodes WebP images into GDI+ Bitmap objects using the libwebp decoder API. Document the core methods: Load, Decode, GetThumbnailFast, and GetThumbnailQuality, including their usage patterns and performance characteristics. Describe the internal process of reading WebP headers via WebPGetFeatures, allocating BitmapData with proper pixel formats (Format24bppRgb or Format32bppArgb based on alpha channel detection), and using WebPDecodeBGR/BGRAInto for direct memory copying. Detail the WebPDecoderConfig usage in advanced decoding with support for cropping, scaling, and dithering. Explain the two thumbnail modes: fast (bypass filtering, no fancy upsampling) vs. quality (full filtering). Include practical examples of loading WebP files from disk and decoding clipboard image data. Address common issues such as memory management with GCHandle pinning, exception handling during decode failures, and version compatibility with libwebp DLLs.

wiki_catalogs.name: IStyleItemPanel UI Interface
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the IStyleItemPanel interface that defines the contract between style items and their configuration UI components. Explain the bidirectional communication pattern through SetStyleItem and GetStyleItem methods, enabling configuration binding and state retrieval. Document how this interface supports the plugin architecture by decoupling style logic from presentation. Illustrate with examples such as OpacityStyleItemPanel and ScaleStyleItemPanel that implement this interface to provide user-configurable parameters. Describe the integration flow where StyleItemSetting in CStyleItem invokes GetToolBoxForm, which returns a form implementing IStyleItemPanel, creating a seamless configuration experience. Address common implementation challenges including data validation, UI state synchronization, and handling of DialogResult for configuration acceptance. Provide best practices for designing responsive and accessible configuration panels that adhere to this contract.

wiki_catalogs.name: Rotation and Reflection
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for CRotateStyleItem's implementation of 90°, 180°, and 270° rotations using GDI+'s RotateFlip method with RotateFlipType enums. Explain the automatic window resizing logic that swaps width and height when rotation changes orientation, including the centering calculation using (width - height)/2 offsets. Document the separate vertical and horizontal reflection (flip) operations and their independent toggling. Include usage examples such as correcting portrait screenshots or mirroring UI elements. Address common issues like unintended double-flips and provide troubleshooting guidance for layout misalignment after rotation. Highlight the integration with RotateStyleItemPanel for user configuration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Text Annotation System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the text annotation system implemented by TextTool. Explain how TextTool integrates with ScrapPaintWindow to enable in-place text editing on scraps, including the creation of text layers via AddTextLayerCommand. Document the workflow from mouse click to text input: activation via MouseUp, dynamic TextBox (TextArea) creation, font selection through ScrapPaintTextTool, and finalization via EditEnd or Enter key. Describe the implementation of TextArea with auto-resizing based on content and font changes. Cover configuration options such as default font (Arial, 10pt), text positioning, and layer naming. Include usage scenarios like adding labels or captions, performance considerations for multiple text elements, and troubleshooting common issues such as lost focus, font rendering problems, or improper layer ordering. Address event handling through Editing and ChangedFont delegates for UI synchronization.

wiki_catalogs.name: Timer Style
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the CTimerStyleItem class that introduces time-delayed execution of style operations through a configurable interval ranging from 100ms to 60 seconds. Explain how the Timer object is utilized to defer subsequent style processing, enabling automation workflows such as delayed screen annotations or timed tutorial sequences. Document the configuration parameters including Interval property validation, default values, and bounds checking. Include usage examples like scheduling a scrap deletion after 30 seconds or delaying opacity changes for visual effects. Cover implementation details such as event subscription to Timer.Tick, thread safety considerations, and proper disposal to prevent memory leaks. Address common issues including inaccurate timing due to UI thread congestion and provide solutions like using high-resolution timers or offloading delays to background threads. Discuss performance implications of multiple concurrent timers and recommend best practices for managing timer lifecycle in long-running sessions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Lossless Encoding
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for lossless WebP encoding functionality. Explain how the EncodeLossless methods preserve all image data during compression using the libwebp library. Document both overloads: the simple version without parameters and the advanced version with speed parameter. Detail the internal process of validating input, locking bitmap data, and calling UnsafeNativeMethods (WebPEncodeLosslessBGR/EncodeLosslessBGRA). Include practical examples of using lossless encoding for archiving high-quality images or when pixel-perfect reproduction is required. Address common issues such as larger file sizes compared to lossy encoding, supported pixel formats, and dimension limits. Provide guidance on when to use lossless encoding versus other formats and performance considerations for different speed settings.

wiki_catalogs.name: Library Version Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the GetVersion method that retrieves the embedded libwebp library version. Explain how the method converts the raw integer return value from WebPGetDecoderVersion into a human-readable major.minor.revision format. Document the importance of version checking for feature compatibility, particularly for functions like EncodeNearLossless that require minimum library versions. Provide practical examples of implementing version guards in application code to enable or disable advanced features based on runtime library capabilities. Address common issues such as version mismatch between encoder and decoder components, interpreting version numbers for backward compatibility, and troubleshooting feature availability based on version reports. Include guidance on using version information for diagnostic reporting and user support scenarios.

wiki_catalogs.name: Advanced WebP Decoding Options
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for advanced WebP decoding using the Decode method with WebPDecoderOptions in the WebPWrapper class. Explain how the WebPDecoderConfig structure enables advanced features such as cropping, scaling, threading, and dithering control. Document each option parameter: use_cropping with crop dimensions, use_scaling with target dimensions, bypass_filtering, no_fancy_upsampling, dithering_strength, and thread usage. Describe the decoding pipeline from options configuration to WebPDecode invocation, including validation of crop boundaries against image dimensions. Provide code examples demonstrating how to implement region extraction, resolution scaling, and quality/performance trade-offs. Address error handling for invalid configurations and version compatibility concerns with libwebp. Discuss performance implications of different option combinations and memory management during complex decode operations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Interactive Style Tools
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for interactive style tools that require user input during application, such as trimming or rotating images. Explain how these styles override the Apply() method to launch interactive UI elements like TrimWindow or rotation dialogs. Document the use of ToolBoxForm implementations (e.g., TrimWindow) that capture user input and modify the scrap state accordingly. Detail the integration between CStyleItem and its associated IStyleItemPanel for configuration, including event handling and state synchronization. Use CTrimStyleItem as a primary example to show how temporary visual feedback (selection rectangle) is provided during interaction. Describe how click coordinates (Point clickpoint) are used to initialize tool positioning. Address implementation challenges such as maintaining UI responsiveness, handling cancellation, and ensuring proper disposal of temporary forms. Provide best practices for designing intuitive interactive tools with clear visual feedback and keyboard/mouse interaction support.

wiki_catalogs.name: Core Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the core application structure. Describe the high-level design based on Windows Forms with event-driven architecture and singleton managers. Explain the role of Mainform as the central UI controller and Program.cs as the entry point. Detail the component interactions between ScrapBook (central registry), LayerManager (z-order control), and CacheManager (persistence). Document architectural patterns including plugin-style style items, event listeners (IFormActivatedListener, IScrapStyleListener), and MVC-like separation. Include system context diagrams showing data flow from capture to persistence. Address cross-cutting concerns like configuration management via SetunaOption and inter-process communication through SingletonApplication. Specify technology stack including System.Windows.Forms, System.Drawing, and Newtonsoft.Json.

wiki_catalogs.name: Magnifier Tool
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the Magnifier tool that assists users in precise region selection. Explain the implementation of Magnifier class that captures and scales a small area around the mouse cursor in real-time. Document how it integrates with CaptureForm to provide live preview during selection. Include details on rendering techniques using Bitmap and Graphics objects, double buffering to prevent flicker, and update frequency optimization. Provide code examples showing how screen pixels are sampled and scaled. Address common issues such as lag during rapid cursor movement, color distortion due to scaling algorithms, and compatibility with high-DPI displays. Discuss performance trade-offs between update speed and visual quality.

wiki_catalogs.name: Layer System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the layer system focused on controlling the z-order and stacking behavior of scrap windows. Explain how LayerManager, a singleton, uses a dictionary (formDic) to track all scrap windows and a sorting list (sortingFormDatas) to manage their order. Detail the RefreshLayer method, which sets TopMost on all tracked forms in the correct order, and the GetNextSortingOrder method, which assigns a unique sorting value to each window upon activation. Describe the event-driven integration with FormManager and WindowManager, which triggers layer updates when windows are shown, activated, or when other system windows change. Document the role of FormData as a wrapper for form state and the optimization performed by OptimizeLayerCounter to prevent integer overflow. Include practical examples of how a scrap window gains topmost status when clicked and how the system handles external window activations. Address common issues like window focus conflicts and performance considerations when managing numerous scraps.

wiki_catalogs.name: Program Entry Point and Application Initialization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Program class as the entry point of the SETUNA application. Explain its static Main method as the application startup routine that handles DPI awareness settings for compatibility across Windows versions. Detail the use of SingletonApplication to ensure only one instance of SETUNA runs at a time, preventing duplicate processes. Describe the initialization sequence including enabling visual styles, creating the Mainform instance, and registering it with the singleton mechanism. Document the command-line argument processing through CommandRun and the application message loop via Application.Run. Explain the integration with Windows APIs for process-level settings and the delayed initialization pattern using timers. Include examples of how external startups are detected and handled through ISingletonForm interface. Address common deployment issues related to DPI scaling and multiple instance prevention.

wiki_catalogs.name: UI Integration and User Interaction
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the UI integration of style items through the IStyleItemPanel interface and its implementations. Explain how the component-based UI architecture allows each style item to provide its own configuration interface via GetToolBoxForm and SetTunedStyleItem methods. Document the lifecycle of a style configuration session: from StyleItemSetting invocation to dialog display and result application. Describe specific implementations like ScaleStyleItemPanel for resizing controls, OpacityStyleItemPanel for transparency adjustment, and PicasaStyleItemPanel for upload configuration. Include details on data binding, validation, and state persistence within these panels. Provide examples showing how user input in ScaleStyleItemPanel translates to CScaleStyleItem properties. Address accessibility considerations and responsive design patterns used in these forms.

wiki_catalogs.name: Restore Mechanism
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the cache restoration mechanism. Explain the Init() method's sequence: directory creation, CacheItem reading from subdirectories, sorting by SortingOrder, and asynchronous addition to ScrapBook via AddScrapFromCache. Detail the recursive AddScrap() method that prevents UI blocking during startup by using continuation callbacks. Document the validation process that checks IsValid property before restoring a scrap. Address edge cases such as corrupted cache directories, missing image files, or invalid JSON data. Explain how the restoration process integrates with the scrap lifecycle by setting CacheItem references on restored scraps. Include performance considerations for large cache sizes and potential optimization strategies like parallel loading or progress indication.

wiki_catalogs.name: Startup Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for startup configuration focused on application initialization and system integration. Explain how the SetunaOption class manages startup behavior through the AppType enumeration (ApplicationMode/ResidentMode) and ShowMainWindow flag, and how these settings are persisted to XML configuration. Detail the implementation of AutoStartup.cs that handles Windows Registry modifications for HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to enable/disable automatic startup. Document the UI implementation in OptionForm with the '开机自启动' checkbox and its interaction with the AutoStartup utility. Include practical examples of checking registry entries, handling different Windows versions, and the relationship between startup type and taskbar presence. Address common issues like permission errors during registry modification, startup script conflicts, and debugging startup behavior. Explain how these settings affect the user experience during system boot and application lifecycle management.

wiki_catalogs.name: UI Controls and ToolStrip Elements
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create in-depth documentation for ToolStripStyleButton, a custom ToolStripMenuItem that encapsulates a CStyle instance for direct application on Scraps. Explain its constructor overloads that accept style objects and optional images, and how it uses the OnClick override to apply the style to the associated Scrap from the ContextStyleMenuStrip owner. Detail image lifecycle management in the Dispose method to prevent memory leaks. Illustrate how this control enables dynamic, style-driven UI generation in context menus and toolbars. Provide usage examples showing integration with StyleItem panels and serialization via StyleItemDictionary. Discuss best practices for extending this pattern with new style UI elements and ensuring visual consistency across different DPI settings. Address common pitfalls like improper image disposal and event handler retention.

wiki_catalogs.name: Hotkey IDs and Mapping
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the HotKeyID enumeration and its role in the hotkey system architecture. Explain how the enum values (Capture, Function1) serve as identifiers that map global hotkey events to specific application functions. Document the __Count__ sentinel value used for array sizing and bounds checking in hotkey management. Describe how these IDs integrate with the main application logic in Mainform.cs to dispatch actions based on received hotkey messages. Provide examples of how new hotkey functions can be added by extending this enum and updating the corresponding handler logic. Address type safety benefits of using enums over magic numbers and discuss potential limitations of the current two-entry design. Include guidance on maintaining backward compatibility when modifying the hotkey ID system.

wiki_catalogs.name: Style Item Extension System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the style item plugin architecture. Explain how CStyleItem serves as the abstract base class for all image transformation plugins, implementing IScrapStyle and ICloneable. Document key methods including Apply (core transformation logic), GetToolBoxForm (UI integration), and SetTunedStyleItem (configuration persistence). Describe the IStyleItemPanel interface contract for bidirectional communication between style items and their configuration UI. Include examples of implementing custom style items like image filters or upload services. Detail the lifecycle from user interaction through context menu to Apply invocation on ScrapBase instances. Address common extension patterns such as adding new image effects, integrating third-party services (e.g., Picasa), and creating composite styles. Provide troubleshooting guidance for UI binding issues and state management.

wiki_catalogs.name: Special Effect Styles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for special effect style items that apply unique visual transformations or behavioral modifications to scraps. Explain how CToneReverseStyleItem implements grayscale inversion using GDI+ ColorMatrix to flip RGB values, creating negative image effects. Document CTimerStyleItem's role in introducing time delays with configurable intervals (100ms-60s) for automation workflows. Include usage examples such as creating inverted color schemes for accessibility or implementing timed sequences in tutorials. Cover implementation details like ColorMatrix configuration and interval validation, configuration parameters including minimum/maximum timer values, and performance considerations for real-time effects. Address common issues like unintended color space conversions and provide troubleshooting guidance for timing inaccuracies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Style Serialization and Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for style serialization and configuration persistence. Explain how the SetunaOption class implements XML serialization to persist both predefined and user-defined styles between application sessions. Document the ConfigFile property's role in determining the configuration file path (SetunaConfig.xml) and directory creation. Describe the GetAllType method's purpose in providing type information for the XmlSerializer to properly serialize complex style objects. Explain the cloning mechanism in the Clone method that ensures deep copying of style configurations. Detail the application startup process where style configurations are loaded from disk and applied to the runtime environment. Address versioning considerations through the OptionVersion property and backward compatibility strategies for style data migration. Provide examples of the XML structure used for style persistence and troubleshooting common serialization issues.

wiki_catalogs.name: WebP Utilities and Metadata
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for WebP utility functions and metadata operations. Explain the GetInfo method's role in extracting metadata from WebP byte arrays, including image dimensions, alpha channel presence, animation status, and format type (lossy/lossless). Document the GetVersion method for retrieving the embedded libwebp library version in major.minor.revision format. Describe the PictureDistortion method for calculating PSNR, SSIM, or LSIM metrics between two images to measure encoding quality. Include practical examples of using GetInfo to validate WebP data before processing and using version checks for feature compatibility. Address common issues such as handling malformed WebP data, interpreting version numbers for feature availability, and performance considerations for distortion calculations (CPU-intensive operation). Provide guidance on integrating these utilities into image validation pipelines and quality testing workflows.

wiki_catalogs.name: Extension Implementation Patterns
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for common extension patterns in the style item system. Document the process of creating new image transformation plugins by extending CStyleItem and implementing required abstract methods. Explain patterns for different categories: simple transformations (e.g., COpacityStyleItem), interactive tools (e.g., CTrimStyleItem), and service integrations (e.g., CPicasaUploaderStyleItem). Detail the implementation of configuration panels by creating classes that implement IStyleItemPanel and integrate with ToolBoxForm. Describe the registration process through StyleItemDictionary and discovery via reflection. Include advanced patterns such as composite styles that apply multiple transformations, conditional application logic using IsInitApply, and time-delayed operations using _waitinterval. Provide step-by-step examples of implementing a custom style item for image filtering or cloud upload. Address troubleshooting for common issues like UI binding failures, configuration persistence problems, and event handling in isolated style contexts.

wiki_catalogs.name: Advanced Encoding Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for advanced WebP encoding configuration through the AdvancedEncode method. Explain how this internal method serves as the central encoding engine for both lossy and lossless operations by accepting a WebPConfig structure. Document how configuration parameters like quality, speed, autofilter, preprocessing, and alpha channel optimization are set in the WebPConfig object before encoding. Detail the conditional logic based on libwebp version (WebPGetDecoderVersion) that enables or disables certain features. Explain the memory management process, including proper disposal of unmanaged resources via WebPFree. Include practical examples of how different configuration settings affect compression ratio and encoding time. Address common issues such as version compatibility, memory leaks, and optimal configuration presets for various use cases.

wiki_catalogs.name: Image Distortion Metrics
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the GetPictureDistortion method that calculates PSNR, SSIM, or LSIM metrics between two images. Explain the method's role in measuring encoding quality by comparing source and reference bitmaps using three different distortion algorithms (0=PSNR, 1=SSIM, 2=LSIM). Document the CPU-intensive nature of these calculations and the method's internal use of WebPPicture structures for image data preparation. Provide practical examples of using distortion metrics to evaluate compression quality across different encoding settings, implement quality assurance pipelines, and perform regression testing on image processing workflows. Address common issues such as dimension mismatch errors, performance optimization strategies (e.g., sampling subsets), and interpreting the five-element float array return value (Y/U/V/Alpha/All). Include guidance on selecting appropriate metrics for different image types and quality requirements.

wiki_catalogs.name: WebP Thumbnail Generation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for WebP thumbnail generation functionality in the WebPWrapper class, focusing on GetThumbnailFast and GetThumbnailQuality methods. Explain the architectural differences between the two approaches: fast mode (bypass_filtering=1, no_fancy_upsampling=1) for performance versus quality mode (full filtering, fancy upsampling) for visual fidelity. Document the shared workflow of using WebPDecoderConfig with scaling parameters, memory pinning, and direct BitmapData manipulation. Describe how alpha channel detection influences output format selection (Format32bppArgb vs Format24bppRgb). Include practical examples of generating thumbnails for UI previews and file browsing. Address performance benchmarks between the two modes, memory consumption patterns, and error handling during thumbnail creation. Provide guidance on selecting the appropriate method based on use case requirements.

wiki_catalogs.name: Service Integration Styles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for style items that integrate with external services, exemplified by CPicasaUploaderStyleItem. Explain how these styles encapsulate authentication credentials (ID, Pass), service configuration (album name, privacy settings), and secure storage patterns using byte arrays. Document the implementation of Apply() to instantiate and display service-specific UI components (e.g., PicasaBar) that handle asynchronous operations. Detail the data flow from configuration panel (PicasaStyleItemPanel) through the style item to the service accessor (PicasaAccessor). Describe patterns for handling service errors (e.g., login failures, upload timeouts) and user feedback mechanisms. Explain how sensitive data is managed and persisted securely within the configuration system. Provide guidance on implementing new service integrations, including OAuth considerations, rate limiting, and error recovery. Address common issues like credential persistence, cross-thread UI access, and service API version compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: Screenshot Capture System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the screenshot capture system. Thoroughly explain implementation details of CaptureForm including region selection, crosshair cursor, and magnifier integration. Document the capture workflow from hotkey activation to scrap creation. Explain the role of CaptureSelLine in visual feedback and SelLineType in selection styling. Include usage patterns for full-screen vs. region capture, mouse cursor inclusion, and high-DPI handling. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how RGBColor and CaptureInfo manage visual elements. Address common issues like inaccurate selection on multi-monitor setups and performance optimization for real-time magnification. Explain integration with WindowsAPI for low-level screen capture.

wiki_catalogs.name: Capture Workflow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the end-to-end capture workflow from activation to scrap creation. Explain how hotkey events trigger CaptureForm initialization, followed by screen overlay and user input handling. Document the sequence from region selection to image extraction using WindowsAPI screen capture functions. Describe how captured images are passed to ScrapBook for registration and instantiated as ScrapBase windows. Include code examples showing how bitmap data is transferred between components and how window positioning is calculated. Address error handling for failed captures, memory management for large images, and thread safety during UI updates. Provide troubleshooting guidance for issues like black screenshots, incorrect positioning, and resource leaks.

wiki_catalogs.name: LayerManager - Window Z-Order Control
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the LayerManager class responsible for managing the z-order of application windows in SETUNA. Explain its singleton pattern implementation and role in maintaining the correct stacking order of scrap windows to ensure they remain on top of other applications. Detail the internal data structures including formDic for tracking window handles and sortingFormDatas for maintaining the display order. Describe the event-driven refresh mechanism triggered by WindowManager and FormManager events, and the RefreshLayer method that enforces topmost behavior. Explain the sorting algorithm based on SortingOrder values and the optimization routine OptimizeLayerCounter to prevent integer overflow. Document the integration with WindowManager and FormManager through event subscriptions, and the FormData class that encapsulates window state information. Include performance considerations for frequent layer refreshes and strategies for minimizing visual flicker.

wiki_catalogs.name: Style Persistence and Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for style persistence and management mechanisms. Explain how predefined styles are implemented in CPreStyles through the GetPreStyle method and static style lists. Document how user-defined styles are stored and retrieved via SetunaOption.FindStyle and the Styles collection. Describe the role of StyleEditForm in creating and modifying custom styles, including its integration with CStyle objects through the Style property. Detail the XML serialization process that persists style configurations between sessions. Explain the distinction between temporary application of styles and permanent saving to configuration. Provide examples of how built-in styles like CAllHideStyle are registered and accessed. Address versioning considerations and backward compatibility for style data.

wiki_catalogs.name: Composite and Delayed Operation Styles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for advanced style implementation patterns including composite styles and time-delayed operations. Explain how CTimerStyleItem uses the _waitinterval field to introduce delays between style applications, enabling animation sequences or timed workflows. Document the IsInitApply property's role in controlling whether a style applies immediately upon scrap creation. Describe how composite styles can be built by chaining multiple CStyleItem instances within a single CStyle container, allowing batch transformations. Detail the registration mechanism via StyleItemDictionary and reflection-based instantiation. Provide examples of building a 'Capture & Upload' composite style that combines screenshot capture with cloud upload. Explain how configuration panels (IStyleItemPanel implementations) manage complex state for multi-step operations. Address challenges such as maintaining execution order, handling partial failures, and debugging asynchronous style chains. Include performance considerations for long-running or frequently applied composite styles.

wiki_catalogs.name: Scrap Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for scrap management focused on the lifecycle and window management of captured images. Explain how ScrapBook maintains a registry of all active scraps and coordinates their behavior. Detail ScrapBase as the base class for individual scrap windows, including properties like location, size, opacity, and z-order. Describe LayerManager's role in controlling window hierarchy using WindowsAPI calls. Document features like persistent positioning across restarts, compact mode, and visibility toggling. Include practical examples of scrap restoration from cache and layer reordering. Address common issues like window focus conflicts and performance considerations when managing numerous scraps.

wiki_catalogs.name: CacheManager - Persistent Storage System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the CacheManager class that handles persistent storage of scraps across application sessions. Explain its implementation of multiple listener interfaces (IScrapAddedListener, IScrapRemovedListener, etc.) to automatically persist scrap state changes to disk. Detail the initialization process in Init that restores previously saved scraps from the local application data directory. Describe the directory structure under %LocalAppData%\SETUNA and the CacheItem serialization mechanism. Explain the event handlers for location changes, image modifications, and style applications that trigger automatic saving. Document the asynchronous restoration process using recursive callbacks to prevent UI blocking. Include the integration with ScrapBase through the CacheItem property and the lifecycle management where cache items are created on scrap addition and deleted on removal. Address data integrity concerns and recovery strategies for corrupted cache entries.

wiki_catalogs.name: Style System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the style system that enables image manipulation on scraps. Explain the architecture of CStyle as the container for style items and CStyleItem as the base class for individual transformations. Document the plugin-style extensibility through implementations like CScaleStyleItem, CRotateStyleItem, and CPaintStyleItem. Describe how StyleItemDictionary maps style types to UI panels. Include usage patterns for applying styles via context menus and hotkeys. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how CToneReverseStyleItem inverts colors or how CTimerStyleItem adds countdown overlays. Address common issues like style application order and performance impact of complex operations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the configuration system focused on user preferences and persistent settings. Explain how SetunaOption serializes configuration to XML using System.Xml.Serialization and manages default values. Detail the UI implementation in OptionForm with tabs for General, Capture, Miscellaneous, and Startup settings. Document the relationship with Settings.Designer.cs for application-level settings. Include practical examples of configuring hotkeys, DPI settings, and startup behavior. Address common issues like settings not persisting and migration between versions. Explain how configuration affects core functionality such as hotkey registration and display behavior.

wiki_catalogs.name: Cache and Persistence
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the cache and persistence system. Detail how CacheManager uses CacheItem to store serialized scrap data including image, position, and style information. Explain the data lifecycle from scrap creation to disk storage and restoration on startup. Document the role of ScrapSource and its derivatives (ScrapSourceImage, ScrapSourcePath, ScrapSourceUrl) in maintaining image provenance. Include database schema-like details of the XML structure used for persistence. Address data access patterns during application restart and performance considerations for large numbers of cached scraps. Specify data retention policies and error handling for corrupted cache files.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Interface
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the user interface components. Describe the main interface in Mainform including system tray integration, notification icon behavior, and global activation via taskbar click. Document the context menu system implemented in ContextStyleMenuStrip with dynamic style application. Explain ToolStripStyleButton and related controls for UI consistency. Include usage examples of right-click interactions, drag-and-drop support, and compact mode toggling. Provide guidelines for accessibility and high-DPI rendering. Address cross-browser compatibility for drag-from-web scenarios and performance optimization for frequent UI updates.

wiki_catalogs.name: Hotkey System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the hotkey system. Document how HotkeyControl registers global hotkeys using Windows API calls and maps them to HotKeyID constants. Explain the message handling in HotkeyMsg for intercepting WM_HOTKEY messages. Include details on hotkey registration lifecycle (register/unregister) and conflict resolution. List default hotkeys for capture, show/hide all scraps, and other operations. Provide client implementation guidelines for adding custom hotkeys. Address security considerations around global input hooks and performance implications of frequent hotkey checks. Include troubleshooting tips for unresponsive hotkeys and OS permission issues.

wiki_catalogs.name: Plugin System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the plugin system focused on extensibility points. Explain how WebPWrapper enables support for WebP image format through external library integration. Document ResourceExtractor's role in embedded resource management. Describe the extension points available for developers including IStyleItemPanel for custom UI and CStyleItem for new image transformations. Include usage examples of adding new style types and integrating third-party services like Picasa upload. Address common issues like DLL loading failures and version compatibility. Provide guidelines for creating and distributing plugins.

wiki_catalogs.name: Development Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the development guide focused on building and contributing to the project. Explain the build process including x86 platform requirement and F5 debugging setup. Document project structure and dependencies including Newtonsoft.Json and System.Drawing. Provide testing guidelines using SETUNATests project and LayerManagerTests as example. Include contribution workflow, coding standards, and pull request procedures. Address common development issues like high-DPI debugging and resource embedding. Provide performance optimization tips for graphics operations and memory management. Reference README.md for version-specific build notes.

wiki_items.title: Program Entry Point and Application Initialization

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: SETUNA

## 1. Project Introduction

SETUNA is a Windows desktop application designed for screenshot capture and image manipulation. The application enables users to capture screenshots, apply various styles and transformations to captured images, and manage them as floating "scraps" on the desktop. Its core functionality revolves around image capture, manipulation through customizable styles, and clipboard operations.

The primary objectives of SETUNA are to provide a flexible screenshot tool with immediate post-capture editing capabilities, support for keyboard shortcuts and hotkeys, and a system for managing captured images through features like a recycle bin (dustbox) and persistent storage. The target audience includes users who frequently work with screenshots and need quick, efficient tools for capturing and manipulating visual content without relying on external image editors.

## 2. Technical Architecture

The application follows a modular desktop application architecture built on Windows Forms, with a clear separation of concerns between UI components, business logic, and configuration management. The architecture is centered around a main form that manages the application lifecycle and coordinates between various subsystems.

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Mainform] --> B[ScrapBook]
    A --> C[SetunaOption]
    A --> D[CacheManager]
    A --> E[LayerManager]
    B --> F[ScrapBase]
    C --> G[Style Management]
    G --> H[CStyle]
    H --> I[CStyleItem]
    F --> J[Image Manipulation]
    A --> K[Hotkey System]
    K --> L[Windows API]
```

The system employs an event-driven architecture where components communicate through events and listeners. The `ScrapBook` acts as a central registry for all captured images (scraps), while the `SetunaOption` class manages application configuration and user preferences. The application uses a style-based system for applying transformations to scraps, where each style can contain multiple style items that perform specific operations.

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- [Program.cs](e:\develop\screenshot2doc\SETUNA\Program.cs)
- [Mainform.cs](e:\develop\screenshot2doc\SETUNA\Mainform.cs)

### Core Modules
- [ScrapBook.cs](e:\develop\screenshot2doc\SETUNA\Main\ScrapBook.cs)
- [ScrapBase.cs](e:\develop\screenshot2doc\SETUNA\Main\ScrapBase.cs)
- [CStyle.cs](e:\develop\screenshot2doc\SETUNA\Main\Style\CStyle.cs)
- [CStyleItem.cs](e:\develop\screenshot2doc\SETUNA\Main\StyleItems\CStyleItem.cs)
- [SetunaOption.cs](e:\develop\screenshot2doc\SETUNA\Main\Option\SetunaOption.cs)

### Configuration Approach
- [SetunaOption.cs](e:\develop\screenshot2doc\SETUNA\Main\Option\SetunaOption.cs)
- [Settings.Designer.cs](e:\develop\screenshot2doc\SETUNA\Properties\Settings.Designer.cs)

### External Dependencies
- Windows Forms (System.Windows.Forms)
- System.Drawing
- System.Xml.Serialization for configuration persistence

### Integration Points
- Windows API for hotkey registration
- Clipboard operations for image import/export
- File system for image persistence
- System events for application lifecycle management

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Program.cs] --> B[Mainform]
    B --> C[ScrapBook]
    C --> D[ScrapBase]
    B --> E[SetunaOption]
    E --> F[Styles]
    F --> G[CStyleItem]
    B --> H[HotkeyManager]
    H --> I[WindowsAPI]
    D --> J[Image Processing]
```

## 4. Key Features

### Screenshot Capture and Management
The application provides comprehensive screenshot capture functionality with the ability to manage captured images as floating desktop elements. The `ScrapBook` class serves as the central manager for all captured scraps, handling their lifecycle from creation to disposal.

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> Capturing: StartCapture
    Capturing --> ProcessCapture: CaptureComplete
    ProcessCapture --> CreateScrap: ImageAvailable
    CreateScrap --> Managed: AddedToScrapBook
    Managed --> Modified: StyleApplied
    Modified --> Saved: ExportedToFile
    Managed --> Deleted: RemovedFromScrapBook
    Deleted --> Recycled: MovedToDustBox
    Recycled --> [*]: PermanentlyRemoved
```

### Style-Based Image Transformation System
SETUNA implements a flexible style system that allows users to apply various transformations to captured images. Each style can contain multiple style items that perform specific operations such as scaling, opacity adjustment, rotation, and border effects.

The style system is extensible, with a base `CStyle` class that can contain multiple `CStyleItem` instances. Each style item represents a specific transformation operation and can be configured through a toolbox interface. Styles can be triggered by keyboard shortcuts or through the application's context menu.

Sources:
- [CStyle.cs](e:\develop\screenshot2doc\SETUNA\Main\Style\CStyle.cs)
- [CStyleItem.cs](e:\develop\screenshot2doc\SETUNA\Main\StyleItems\CStyleItem.cs)

### Hotkey and Shortcut Management
The application features a comprehensive hotkey system that allows users to trigger various functions through keyboard shortcuts. The `Program.cs` entry point registers hotkeys for screenshot capture and other functions, while the `SetunaOption` class manages the configuration of these shortcuts.

The hotkey system integrates with Windows API functions to register global hotkeys that work even when the application is minimized. The system supports modifier keys (Ctrl, Alt, Shift) combined with regular keys to create a wide range of possible shortcuts.

Sources:
- [Program.cs](e:\develop\screenshot2doc\SETUNA\Program.cs#L11-L31)
- [SetunaOption.cs](e:\develop\screenshot2doc\SETUNA\Main\Option\SetunaOption.cs#L707-L734)

### Persistent Configuration and State Management
SETUNA uses XML serialization to persist user preferences and application state between sessions. The `SetunaOption` class contains all configurable settings and is serialized to an XML file on disk. The application loads these settings at startup and saves them when configuration changes are made.

The configuration system includes default settings that are applied when no configuration file exists, ensuring the application works out of the box. The `GetDefaultOption` method in `SetunaOption` initializes a comprehensive set of default styles and preferences.

Sources:
- [SetunaOption.cs](e:\develop\screenshot2doc\SETUNA\Main\Option\SetunaOption.cs#L18-L570)
- [Mainform.cs](e:\develop\screenshot2doc\SETUNA\Mainform.cs#L420-L448)
</blog>
